summary.seg: This composite manuscript predominantly contains a Middle English translation of the Circa Instans, a Latin work on the medicinal properties of plants, animals, and minerals, which was attributed to the Salernitan physician Matthaeus Platearius. The manuscript also contains a Middle English translation by Nicholas Bollard of Godfridus super Palladium de agricultura, a manual that instructs readers how to graft and cultivate trees, and the translator's own Book of Grafting and Planting. It also features various medical and alchemical recipes and tracts.

While the manuscript's first part (ff. 1r-96v) [identified as Part 2 in this catalogue record because it is preceded by a single leaf from an older medieval manuscript that has been reused as an endleaf for this manuscript] may have been written slightly earlier than its second part (ff. 97r-151v) [Part 3 in this catalogue record], the 16th-century ownership inscriptions that occur in both parts indicate that they have been joined together from an early stage.

The cataloguing of this manuscripts has made visible the extensive ownership notes and legal texts that were added by one of its earliest owners: Henry Hancoke (fl. c. 1573) of Stubley in the parish of Dronfield, Derbyshire.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: The manuscript opens with two parchment leaves (ff. i-ii) taken from another manuscript [Part 1]; the remainder of the manuscript consists of two separate parts [Parts 2 and 3] consisting of paper leaves (ff. 1-151).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Folio numbers 140 and 152 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).

signatures.p: Letters ('a'-'m') and Roman numerals in the lower right-hand corners of the first halves of quires, often no longer visible due to cropping of the leaves

additions.p: Marginal additions by Henry Hancoke, fl. c. 1573 Hancoke, Henry, fl. c. 1573 of Stubley in the parish of Dronfield, Derbyshire concerning drafts of letters and indentures:

list.item: f. ii verso: two untranscribed marginal words that may be in Hancoke's hand.
f. 20r: After my most harty commend[ations] vnto yow stryfeng to god that yow by in good helt as I wasse at the makying herof peressed by all mygth god.
f. 40v: Robart hepenstow of.
f. 43v: thes is to let yow have vnderstand [...].
f. 49v: In the nam of god Amen In the xv day of Augest in the yeare of owr loord 1573 I thomas Cotlaws of Nort.

f. 50r: Wylliam stenrood of dronffeld in the name of god Amen I have my most harti commendations vnto yow mathay massone of london / in the name of god amen I have my most harti commendasion vnto yow my son Wylliam more of Bradwey.
f. 67v: Rememberans mak thys my lat wyll and testament exsep I tak any other mean[es] ffor.
f. 74v: In the name of god amen in the x day of Januari in the year of owr Lord 1572 I Robart Barkar of brampton in the conty of.

f. 75r: This indayntur mad the first day of ffebruary in the xv yeare of the regne of owr soverant Lady quene Elyzabeth by the, and Rychard sheather of sheffeld is my name / And with my hand I wrot the same - In the name of god Amen I Robart Woodus of tootle in the parishe of dronfeld in the conty of darby yoman.

f. 80r: wyt dyssar lendes to the som belongin heiris to be moted that I Robart Woodos of Totle in the par[i]she of drouffeld in the conty of Darby yomon of the town parte Wyliam mason of stobbe in the sam paryshe of the other party wher.

f. 82r: Thys indentur mad the ix day of march in the first yere of the rean', and 'To my derly beloved father and mother in Low wyll haslam of Dronffeld in the conty of Darby yomon of the tone party and Elisabethe oxser cooffte of the othar party [...].

f. 96v: To my loveyeng forynd Thomas hancok of stuble in the Conty of Darby yoman of the the one party and Robart Hepanstow of Draufeld and Thes indenture made the xxv day of may in the xiiij yera of the Ren of owre soverant Lady [quene] Elizabethe by the grasse of god quen of England bytwen Robart hancok of stuble in the paryshe of drofeld in [the] conty of Darby and Thomas Coutlaf of the same tow[n] and conty of the other party wytness that the aforsed Robart hancok [...].
f. 97r: This to let yow vnderstand that [...].
f. 104r: Henry Arthar the casse of my wrayteng vnto yow at thes [...] is to let you vnderstand of ane.
f. 121r: Darfilde.

additions.p: Other texts apparently in Hancoke's hand include:

list.item: Religious instructions on f. 40r: forst of all aftor mette yow most thank god of heys geyftes gret and low and pres your hevenly kyng and pre hem of heys . dear blesseyng for ever and ever Amen.
Sayings on f. 48r: The father sed to the son hapy wasse hey [...] and f. 49r: The father sed to the sone blesed by the son [...].

signatures.p: Crosses in pencil added to the lower corners of the rectos of the inner leaves of quires.
Arabic numbers in pencil added to the lower corners of the first rectos of quires.

note.p: Collation formula by the hand of H.L. PinkPink, H. L., 1948-1970 (inside back cover).

binding.p: Binding by W. H. Smith and Son Ltd. in London, February 1963, according to a note on the inside cover: Quarter leather with marbled paper covering over millboards and plain pastedowns. The classmark and a title: 'Medica et Alchemica' are tooled in gold on the spine.
Binding height: 210 mm; width: 145 mm; depth: 40 mm.

provenance.p: Richard Slacke (fl. 1572) Slacke, Richard, fl. 1572: owned or accessed the manuscript in 1572: his initials inscribed on f. 139r (Per me R.S. 1572) followed by a note: I Rychard slacke beinge sike in bodye but whole and another note by him on f. 38r and f. 94v: 1572 Mi mestar is sicat heys hart wisen hey wyll amend I canot tell verely bat god amen hem sone if yow cold amen hem wyll geff yow xli of good and lastelle [...] this monet of Dugland at the fest of natyvety of John Baptes nex ensueng; perhaps Richard Slacke (1555-1593) of Derbyshire, son of William Slacke and Alice Scholey.

history.provenance:
Henry Hancoke, fl. c. 1573 Hancoke, Henry, fl. c. 1573 of Stubley in the parish of Dronfield, Derbyshire:
his ownership inscriptions in the margins of:
f. 19r: Henry hancoke off the conty of darby woeth theys bock god ssend hem wyelle ssped of [...] all.
f. 61v: Henry hancok of stuble in the Conty of Darby wohs thes bock.
f. 65v: Henry hancok of stuble in the xxvi day of August in the xv yere of the Ren of owre sover.
f. 92r: Henry hancok of stuble est p[?ossessor].
f. 103v: Henry hancok of stuble woeth thys book.
Hancoke's name is written in the margins of: ff. 16v, 39v, 66r, 92r (with the name Arthor Barekar of totle in Hancoke's hand), 95v, 104v, 107r, 108v, 114v.
Hancoke's name also appears in an erased inscription in the margin of f. 73v, and in a memorandum in the margin of f. 81v: In name of god amen the xv day of August in the year of owr lord M d lxxiij I henry hancok of stuble seyll in bad of good and per[...].

provenance.p: John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 196 (written on f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum AngliÃ¦ et HiberniÃ¦ (c. 1697).

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inner front cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), Index of Middle English Prose, 19 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), A. Timmerman, 'Alchemy in Cambridge: An Annotated Catalogue of Alchemical Texts and Illustrations in Cambridge Repositories', Nuncius, 30:2 (2015), 345-511, and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.13, ff. i recto-ii verso

msItem.title: Liturgical fragment from a funeral service
msItem.incipit: i verso domus mea est et in [tenebris straui lectulum meum] putredini dixi pater meus es mater mea et soror mea vermibus
msItem.explicit: ii verso atque a contagiis mortalitatis exutam in aeternae saluationis partem restitue. per quem
msItem.note: The text on f. i recto is heavily worn and mostly illegible.

extent.seg: Fragment, comprising a bifolium from another manuscript, recycled for use as a pastedown (now lifted) and endleaf.

collation.p: This part of the manuscripts consists of a single bifolium.

supportDesc.condition: The text on f. i recto has become illegible due to rubbing and glue stains, probably because the leaf was once a pastedown.

layout.seg: Ruling in hardpoint, frame and lines. Single columns of about 40 lines. The upper lines are missing due to cropping of the leaves.

decoNote.p: Two-line initials in red, some with minor forms of arabesque decoration.
Headers at the beginning of different sections and letters 'v' and 'r' at the beginning of versicles and responses rubricated in red.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.13, ff. 1r-96v

msContents.textLang: Middle English with dialectal features locatable to Suffolk [see LALME, I: 66-67], and Latin

msItem.title: Herbal (Circa instans)
msItem.author: Matthaeus Plateaurius (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 1r Aloen hath vertu to purge flewme and colour and hit clensith malenkoly and hit comfortyth membres that bethe senewy
msItem.explicit: 91v In suripes .ij. li. of sugur Ã¾er schal be .5. q. of watur and Ã¾owÈ Ã¾er be more watur Ã¾er is non harm but for Ã¾e enduryng amen quod Gerford
msItem.note: Descriptions for the medical purposes of more than 270 herbs, organised in alphabetical order.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 87

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 91v Medicina optima pro scabie et prurito
msItem.explicit: 93v contra malum mortuum
msItem.note: Mainly in Latin, but also including Middle English medical recipes to treat pain in a horse and to treat sciatica on f. 92r. Written in the same hand that copied the recipes on ff. 95r-96v.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 87

msItem.title: A verse
msItem.incipit: 91v Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 95r Caveat pacius ab omni aqua fridiga
msItem.explicit: 96r et reliquam pulveris in panno lineo sicto vulne imponatur etcaetera
msItem.note: Written by the same hand that copied the recipes on ff. 91v-93v.
An erased Middle English recipe on f. 96v.

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded in octavo.
Licorne ( 75 40 ) On the upper edge of the folio, comparable to Briquet 9956. This example is dated to 1405-1417.

list.item: Quires 1-128 (ff. 1-96)

signatures.p: Letters 'a' to 'm' combined with Roman numerals 'i' to 'iiij' written on the lower right corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires 1-12.

supportDesc.condition: Stains throughout but without loss of text. Damaged corners and margins at the beginning and end have been repaired with blank paper; water damage to the final folios has rendered text on the top line illegible on ff. 150v-151v. The text on f. 151v is heavily faded.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Single columns. 27 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p:
This part of the manuscript features two different hands writing in Gothic cursive scripts with features of Anglicana and Secretary:
Hand 1: ff. 1r-91v
Hand 2: ff. 91v-96r
Various short recipes and other texts added by different cursive hands that are dateable to the second half of the 15th century or 16th century throughout.

decoNote.p: Large blue initials throughout ff. 1r-91v, usually two lines high, but the opening initial on f. 1r is three lines high.

additions.note: Medical recipes in English added to the upper margins of 83v-84r in a 16th-century hand, perhaps that of Henry Hancoke (see the Provenance section for further details).

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 15th century

provenance.p: Cristopher Selyoke (fl. 2nd half of the 16th century) Selyoke, Cirstopher, fl. 1550-1600: his ownership inscriptions on f. 1r: 'C.S. verus possesor huius'; and f. 17r: 'Crestofor Selyoke owth this boke god make hym a good man est Amen'. Perhaps the Christopher Selioke of Hazelborough who was granted land in Aston by Godfrey Foljambe of Westwell on 20 October 1572, and who was let a farm in Wadshelf by Oliver Creswell in 1589. Rosemarie Locke, transcription of The Feudal History of the County of Derby Volume 5, Chapter 14 - Various Charters Relating To Tideswell by John Pym Yeatman, pp. 401-416 (2012) https://places.wishful-thinking.org.uk/DBY/Tideswell/Yeatman5Chapter14.html [accessed 25 August 2022]) Rosemary Milward, 'Arthur Mower of Barlow Woodseats, County Derby: A Sixteenth Century Yeoman', Derbyshire Miscellany: The Local History Bulletin of the Derbyshire Archaeological Society, 13:2 (1992), 27-51 (p. 34)

Richard ?Gapson (fl. 2nd half of the 16th century) ?Gapson, Richard, fl. 2nd half of the 16th century: his name inscribed on f. 21r: Rychard Gapson [? Gareson] is me name and wyth my hande I [wrote the same].

William Hasselam [Haselam] (fl. 2nd half of the 16th century) Hasselam [Haselam], William, fl. 2nd half of the 16th century: owned or accessed the manuscript and inscribed his name on f. 39v: Wylliam hasselam of honsfeld is my nam and wyth my hand I wrot the same; and f. 62v: [...] quod ego Willhelmas Hasslam de Hownsfeld in comitato darbe, and f. 95r: Wylliam Haselam est nomen meus.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.1.13, ff. 97-151

msContents.textLang: Middle English with dialectal features locatable to Norfolk [see LALME, I: 66-67], and Latin

msItem.title: Treatise on urinoscopy [Ten Cold Ten Hot]
msItem.incipit: 97r Of which Ã¾e first x be tokynys cold and Ã¾e othir x be tokynyth hete
msItem.explicit: 100v also take hede to the tast whedur it be swet or not swete for swet tast betokynyt hele and oÃ¾er betokynyth siknes. Explicit
msItem.note: Written by a different hand, and the same hand that copied the next item.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 87-88

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 101r A medicin for euil heringe: Take greas fanell uelle and jus and fenigreu of eÃ¾er ilych and medil hem togydyr and holle hem a litil and do it low in Ã¾e hol ere of Ã¾e sike
msItem.explicit: 108r To take an erwyg owt of a manis ere: Take a hote rie lof and hold it to Ã¾yn ere and it xal distroy it in a schort time. Explicit
msItem.note: Collection of seventy-two medical recipes, written by the same hand that copied the preceding item.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 88

msItem.title: Tract on the Perilous Days
msItem.rubric: 107r Here be Ã¾e perlos days of blod letting and Ã¾e good dais to blede or for diuers evilis and Ã¾e perlos dais of birÃ¾e of children and of etyng of gees Ã¾at is for to wit
msItem.incipit: 107r-107r In Ã¾e first iij dais Ã¾at i til if oni man let him blood or fal sik he xal die wiÃ¾ in forti days aftyr
msItem.explicit: 108r whan he is ded he xal neuer rote Ã¾at is to sey Ã¾e first day of januari Ã¾e ij dai and Ã¾e iij day of februari
msItem.note: Embedded in the preceding collection of seventy-two medical recipes.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 88-89

msItem.title: Treatise on betony
msItem.incipit: 108v A man Ã¾at haÃ¾e Ã¾e ston gyf him beteyn and he xal be hole anoun and mak hym wel
msItem.explicit: 108v siluer colour and put Ã¾at in glas and whan nede is do a droppe ther of in thyn ye that is sore
msItem.note: Written by the same hand that copied ff. 97r-108r.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 88

msItem.title: Godfridus super Palladium [The Book of Trees and Wine] (English translation)
msItem.author: Geoffrey of Franconia [Gottfried von Franken]
msItem.incipit: 109r The maner of settyng of trees ys manyfold and so comon Ã¾at we wyl not at Ã¾is tyme schew Ã¾erof but a prevy werkyng towchyng Ã¾e same matyr yt schal be seyde aftyrward in his place pleynely
msItem.explicit: 124r Ã¾er wiÃ¾ Ã¾am Ã¾ei xal be clensid thorow a sachel vp on safron and licoris and it xal be delectabill in sauour and colour. Explicit
msItem.note: English translation of Godfridus super Palladium by Nicholas Bollard, but this copy is missing chapter 60 and parts of chapters 20, 26, 33, 35, 38, 39, and 52.
Written by a different hand, the same hand that copied the next item.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 88

msItem.title: The Book of Planting and Grafting
msItem.author: Nicholas Bollard
msItem.rubric: 124r Her begynyth the tretis of nicolas Bollard
msItem.incipit: 124r The tretis he seyth is partid in iij partes
msItem.explicit: 129v and Ã¾erfo it is not to make here no long trete Ã¾er of but eueri thing if it be wel doun wil bring in and teche oÃ¾er And Ã¾us endith Ã¾e tretis of Nicolas Bollard Explicit
msItem.note: Complete, except for the second half ochapter four of the first part.
Written by the same hand that copied the preceding item.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 89-90

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 129v For castyng take myllyfoylle and stamp ytt and temper ytt wiÃ¾ wyne or wiÃ¾ stale ale and geue the seke to drink iij deye fastyng
msItem.explicit: 130v and qwylkesyluer and medyll them together and anowtt the body and ytt wyll dystrow all Ã¾e lyse and verme of Ã¾e body
msItem.note: Collection of eleven medical recipes written by a different later hand.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 90

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for treating cloth
msItem.incipit: 131r To make red veluet: Take braseyl and greynis and lake of euery alich and cast hem in clene watur and seth hem togydyr
msItem.explicit: 135v and take Ã¾e stonys and het Ã¾em a lityl and ley syment ouer hem and let hem stond togyddyr til Ã¾ei be cold. Explicit
msItem.note: Collection of thirty-seven recipes for treating cloth, perhaps by the same hand that copied copied ff. 97r-108v.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 135v For the stone: Take an egge shelle that a chikon is haught out of and pike awey the pille that is wiÃ¾in
msItem.explicit: 137r floure and bray hem alle togider till it resonable thik then take it and put it in a boxe and that is a goode oynement
msItem.note: Collection of seven medical recipes copied by a different later hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 137r For the pyllys: Take malleuleuys and sellendyne
msItem.explicit: 137r and soke together and and then strene them thorou a klote
msItem.note: Two medical recipes for the pyllys and skyn written by the same hand.

msItem.title: A medical recipe for Sciatica
msItem.incipit: 137v ffor the syatyca: Take rew and sawge wepes mosterd sed neu grond ?and wenger
msItem.note: Full trancription; added by a different hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 137v For all maner of venyme or powson take mylk of a gotte and sethe ytt wiÃ¾ heympseyd
msItem.explicit: 138r For swellyng of ye tethe take rede myntte and stamp ytt well and then putt ytt in a clowthe in Ã¾e jusce with all and ley to Ã¾e tothe.
msItem.note: Collection of nine medical recipes, apparently by the same hand that copied the collection of recipes on ff. 129v-130v.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 91

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 138v For deleyng [...] of swellyng of on legges
msItem.explicit: 138v for Ã¾e same take Ã¾e [...] rynde of a [...] and [...] to powther
msItem.note: Three recipes added by a later hand written in a light faded ink by a different later hand.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to improve eyesight
msItem.incipit: 138v For to sey by nytgh as by day anont ye eye with they blod of a ? bacll and he sall sey by nygth
msItem.note: Full transcription; apparently added in the hand of Richard Slacke (see f. 139r), dated 1572.

msItem.title: Fragment of the prologue to Matthew's gospel from the Wycfliffite New Testament
msItem.incipit: 139v Matheu Ã¾at was of iudee as he is sett fyrst in ordur of Ã¾e gospelares soo he wrett fyrst the gospell in Iudee and and [sic] fro the offys of a tolgederer he was cleped to god when this mathue hadde preched fyrst Ã¾e gospell in Iudde
msItem.note: Full transcription (followed by text that has been crossed out); added by a different later hand.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 92

msItem.title: Two verses
msItem.incipit: 139v Johne Sebastiane with other twane / came latlie out of payne
139v god send vs of his geare / In heaven to have a place / and then no dout all thinges is nor as harte can thinke or tounge can [? taste]
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by a late 16th-century hand, possibly the same hand that also added the English historical note on f. 142r.

msItem.title: Collection of recipes for bookbinding and writing
msItem.incipit: 141r For to make boke glewe take the sowndys of stokfysch and sethe hem in worte or ellys in thynne ale tyl Ã¾at Ã¾ey be tendyr
msItem.explicit: 142r take vytryole and make yt in pouder put yt in a moyst cloth and rub Ã¾er Ã¾ou hast wretyn and yt shal apere Ã¾at Ã¾u mayst rede yt
msItem.note: Collection of eleven recipes for bookbinding and writing copied by a single hand.

listBibl.bibl: Wright and Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps (1845), I: pp. 163-164

msItem.title: A verse
msItem.incipit: 141r Adam primus homo damnauit secula pomo
msItem.note: Full transcription; added upside down in the lower margin in a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Historical note
msItem.incipit: 142r This Titus was his wifes sonne as saith Josephus: Jherusalem distroyed by Titus sonne in lawe to Vaspacian themperor of Rome in which Cittie perished with hounger and with the sworde xjC thousande and systen thousande led captine awaie / besydes a greate sorte which was throwne into the rever of whome is mad ano mension
msItem.note: Full transcription: added upside down in the lower margin in added by a late 16th-century hand, possibly the same hand that also added the English verses on f. 139v.

msItem.author: pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.title: Recipes including Pseudo-Albertus Magnus, Semita recta (English translation)
msItem.incipit: 142v Salt commen ys key berer of Ã¾is craft and he is Ã¾us preparat solue yt in hote watyr and clense Ã¾orow a thyk lynen cloth into a treen wessel
msItem.explicit: 149v and yt schal turne into Ã¾e best sol clennest and most perfite Ã¾at may be. Explicit
msItem.note: Alchemical treatise with recipes copied by the same hand that copied the next two items.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), pp. 92-93

msItem.title: Treatise on making furnaces
msItem.incipit: 150r Sum must be more and sum las aftyr Ã¾e quantite of Ã¾i werke. The philosofors furneys must be made be a wal so Ã¾at he may take wynde
msItem.explicit: 150r Èe must make a crest of erthe to set ouer yowre vessel of calcynacyoun so Ã¾at yowre fyre may be undyr and Ã¾ese be the schappys of Ã¾e furneys
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied the preceding and next item.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 93

msItem.title: Alchemical recipes
msItem.incipit: 150v [...] vessel of erthe Ã¾at Ã¾ou wylt glare and a noynte hym wiÃ¾ past made of wyne lyys and of lunayle of saturne and set yt in Ã¾es furneyce to dry ouer Ã¾e barrys of iren
msItem.explicit: 151v et conuertetur in mercurus et [...] fecerunt Alkymiam
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied the preceding two items.

listBibl.bibl: For other copies, see Connolly (2009), p. 93

msItem.title: Household note
msItem.incipit: 151v To the trenete - xx - vijs - vjd
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Note of a payment or donation to a (?) church; added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

supportDesc.support:
Paper, folded in quarto.
TÃªte de boeuf ( 55 30 ) On the inner center of the folio, comparable to Briquet 15044.This example is dated to 1455.

list.item: Quire 1610-1 (ff. 131-139: 10th leaf missing)
Quire 1712-1 (ff. 141-151: 12th leaf missing)

collation.signatures: Letters 'a' to 'f' used as leaf signatures in quire 14.

supportDesc.condition: This part of the manuscript occasionally features stains. The text on ff. 151r-151v is much faded. The upper margins of ff. 150-151 have been torn and repaired with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only (ff. 97r-137v). Single columns. 20-35 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p:
This part of the manuscript features three different hands writing in Gothic cursive scripts with features of Anglicana and Secretary:
Hand 1: ff. 97r-129v and ff. 130v-135v
Hand 2: ff. 129v-130r and ff. 137v-138r
Hand 3: ff. 142v-151v

decoNote.p: Half-page with drawings of alchemical vessels and furnaces in brown ink on f. 150r.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 15th century.

provenance.p: John Smythe (fl. 1450-1500) Smythe, John, fl. 1450-1600: his name inscribed on f. 151v: John Smythe.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
